The following is a late decree of the King Of
France against the Slave Trade:


"Charles, by the grace of God, King of France
and Navarro, to all who shall see these presents,
greeting.


We have ordained, and do orslain, that the
project of 2 law of the following tenor shall be
presented by our Minister Secretary of State to
the Department Of Marine and the Colonies,
whom We charge to explain its object and to sup
port 1t IN discussion,


Only .4rtscie.--In case Of . cooperation or par
tcipaton, by any means whatever in the traffic
known under the name ofthe negro slave trade,
the propretors, AM supercargocs; the insurers
who ensure it knowingly, the captain or comrnail-
der and other officers ofthe vessel; shall be pun
ishcd with banishnent, and fine equal to the
value OF the ship and cargo.


The finc shall be pronounced conjoin,ly against
the individuals designated in the preceding par
agraph.


The captain and officers shall be further de-
clared incapable Of serving, under any title in
the kiny's navy or The French merchant service.
Other individuals belonging to the crew shall
be punished with imprisonment from months
TO pears. From these are expected, such of
the above mentioned individuals as SHALL within
fifteen days after the vessels arrival, declare to
the commissary of marine, or the magistrates in
the French ports or the French consuls in for
eign ports, the facts which they shall know.


The vessel shall be seized and confiscatsd.


The penalties under the present law are indie
pendent of those which shall be pronounced, in
conformity with the penal code, for other crimes
or offences which may have been committed OH
board the slip.


The law of april Is, 1913, is abrogated


Given in our palace of the Iuileries, Dec. 27
1926; and, of our reign the third.
SLAVE TRADE.

It is our privilege to live in an age Of surpass
ing improvement. The sciences and the arts arc
deeply indebted to the genius and enterprise OF
our contemporaries, and schemes, OF extensive
utility, are now i'll successful operation, Which,
a half century ago, would have been considered
as fit only to supply void in the brain Of maniac,
or to exercise the idle Ingenuity OF a visionary
| protector. by new and etiicacious experiments,
principles in natural science, unknown to our ia
| theirs, have been developed, and new avenues
opened to the enjoyment Of man.


! Oftllose Improvements in physical and politi-
cal science, which have stamped their character
on the last and the passing age, the inhabitants
of the western world claim distinguished share
There ingenuity has displayed its inventions
to the gaze and imitation of the world, and there
the principles OF government have been traced
to their source, and the laws of mmutable us-
tice solemnly proclaimed as the proper basis and
support ofpolitcal institutions.


If we review the periods of our national growth,
and mark our unparalleled progress in the march
of nations, we must subscribe to the sentiment,
that no people have greater cause revercntly to
commemorate the goodness of Beneticent
Creator than the people of these United States.
No where have the choicest blessings of the all
bountifu Parent been spread with amore unspar
ing hand. To no other people, ancient ormodern,
has the cup of felicity been presented with few
er bitter ingredients, or more completely purti-
ed from the lees of political thraldom.


If, Judging the future from the past, We en-
deavour to dclineate our course through ages
yet to come, Il series of pleasing antcipatons
warns the rejecting mind. With afertile soil,
extending through every desirable variety of eli
mate. and capable of affordins all that luxury
! could demand to supply the wants, Or promote
the comfort Of mani with population enlight-
ened and free; with government over which
the laws are supreme, and the people the arbiters
of the law; the way appears open to that nation
al greatness which ambition could not wish to
enhance; and to individual prosperity, in which
discomfort might blush to complain.


Are these the dcusive prospects of a feverish
patriotism, the visions ofpoetry; or are they the
anticipations ofsober reflection Is there no ill
boding omen to dim the light that gttcrs on our
future course1 Alas! one portentous cloud is
impending over some of the farest portions of
our favoured land One dire disease, deeply in
fixed in our national system, has 'sgrown with
our growth. and strengthened with our strength"
The light of freedom, which we so highly prize,
shines on part ofour population only by refiec-
ton, and to them is rather darkness visible" than
light


This appalling subject is forced upon us, how
ever reluctant may feel to investigate its char

The editor being anxious so to conduct his in

4osan IKE, would destroy the Church. He

! am attached to the Catholic church,

ed to be practised OH them by such an un-

i feel consciousness of the correctness

very scurrilous publication appeared over
the signatures OF Peter Pierce, Bernard NJ
Gugen, Bernard M'Cann and John Durnin
self styled Trustees Of the Catholic Church,
in Wilmington, in which my character has
been uniustlv assaled, and most wantouly
sandered. ] feel it duty | owe to myself
and my friends, to repel the unauthorized,
base and unfounded charges made by those
calumniators, and expose them to that CON
tempt they merit; by exhibiting to the pub
lie statement OF the facts connected with
the Lottery case alluded to. as briefly as prac-
ticable, with comment, from which they
may be enabled to form their judgments.


1t may be recollected, that on application
of the Trustees of St. Peters Church, at
Wilmington, the Legislature of Delaware,
in 1922, authorized the raising by Lottery,
for the use of the Church, and payment Of
debts, the sum of three thousand dollars, Co.
yer and beyond all expenses); and in that
law named certain Managers to supcrintend
the Lottery; some in Wilmington ard some
in Philadelphia. In conformity with the
provisions of the law, the Managers pro-
ceeded to discharge the trust confided 70
them. After this period the Managers u.
nites,, in opinion, that one Of them should
sign the Tickets, and receive and make pay
ment of prizes. Unfortunately for me, or.
as the self-created Trustees would have it,
for the Church, was selected for that pur-
pose, the residue OF the Managers giving me
their bond of indemnity against any loss in
the performance of that duty.


The Scheme of this Lottery was sold to
Thomas Hope, Broker, by. and with the
consent OF the Managers, for the sum of
three thousand dollars--to be drawn in Six
classes, payable $500 at the drawing OF each
class. Under that arrangement Mr.. Hope
went on, and drew two classes. For those
two classes paid the Church in cash and
Note, and payment of her debts the full a
mount and upwards, say sixteen hundred
and five dollars and fourteen cents. The
Third class of this Lottery. was subsequent
ly under the direction of Patrick Higgins,
and conducted by him, and many OF the tick
cts in that class remained upsold. The prl-
2es in that class was called on tor, and OBJ
lged to pay; by my signing, ! was pledged
TO redeem them. On Hope failing in his en-
ragemeEts the Fourth class was sold to
Messrs Yates and MIntyre. The money
received for the class drawn by them, ac
cording to contract, was applied (and paid)
to the deficiency of the Sd class, conducted
by Patrick Higgins. All OF these facts.
remain ready and willing to make appear in
j
but 7ohich has never been commenced, altho'
so boldly asserted.


As to the denunciation of my services, by
those "Trustees'', it is truly ridiculous.
know of no powers they possess to grant to
me. Ely hozverS are from higher aud
more respectable source. Those men need
employment themselves, and they viii pro-
badly receive it, of that kind in legal wav
not comfortable to them. a part of the JAuaa
Of the Church, would, no doubt, be very con
venient to our "Gentlemen Trustees" but
which it is hoped the good sense OF the con-
gregation will prevent them from handling:
and az very unfortunate indeed would 1t be for
the Church, to confide her concerns in such
hands, goho have not sufficient discretion to
conduct their own affairs. would observe,
that no dissatisfaction would have arose, but
tor two disorganizing members, one OF whom
undertook to perform part i'll the Lottery,
which his incapacty untitled him for, where
by he was abandoued; and he did not reap

"ai.' ialliiiar with all tile prlvacies of our do


hiestlc me- accustomed to hear liberty extolled


as the highest and noblcst of eniovments; and
yet, hndng the bitter draught of hereditary SER


yitnde its own hopeless portion; incapable, from


its degraded condition, ofappreciatng the bless


ings OF the government under which we live, and


having little to dread from any change or convul-


SONS OF the political world-presents to our


view prospect too awful to- be contemplated


with stole Indifference The cloud is thickening


with the progress of time; and prudence adj
monishes, that, if it cannot be dissipated, it
should, # possible, be dsarmcd ofits lightning.
whether slavery is, or is not a political evil,
or whether free or slave population is most
conducive to national prosperity, can scarcely,
IN tins age and in this country, require a serious
discussion.


If slavery has, in all ages, and among all ma
tons, been considered as among the greatest Of
evils, ii liberty is always the highest wish and ul-
tlmatc aim OF the slave, how repusive must that
condition appear to an observant eve, when con-
trasted with the civil and religious freedom, by
which, in the United States, it is every where
surrounded.


But however we may colnmiserate the condi-
tlon OF those who are doomed to hereditary SER
vittlde, the zeal which this feeling excites NAV
sometimes warm without enlightcning The phi
lanthroplc mind. The slave, sunk and degraded
below the proper level ofhumanty, may find in
the letharglc inscnsibiiity resulting FROM his sit
uation, retreat from mental suffering; vet,
though bent to the yoke, he still Possesses the
stamina OF the human chaiacter--thc aspiring
tendency OF his nature, though suppressed and
concealed, is not destroyed-hs dormant pas


sons are not extinct. The TRANQUILITY which


prevails. may be suddenly ,listirbcd-fur the
sumberng volcano retains its fires, and those


who occupy lis smoking verge may themselves
| l,a 4 g =.
| The slave is not the only object that demands
our consideration. The introduction of negro
slavery into the United States was not the work
OF the present generation. The system was en-
tailed upon them by their ancestors: and Justice
| demands the admission, that evils, both moral
and political, are more easily discovered than re-
moved; and that those who arc subjected, by
the circumstances of their birth, to the hard al
Tentative, either to new model the habits which
! have grown with their years, or to maintain
system which their sober judgments cannot an
prove, are objects of sympathy with the truly
christian mind.


The .iealouses and antpatlles which the dis
| tlnction between slave-holding and non slave
| holding states has cngendered and fed, may be
safely cassed among the disastrous concomitants
OF the system; especially as they oppose stub
born obstacle to any general effort for the reno
val OF the other acknowledged evils of slavery.
Unhapply for the cause of humanity, the advo-
! cate Of the slave has been too often identified
with the antag mist Of his owner The interests
OF these opposite classes have been considered
as incompatible, and friendship for tile one AS
synonymous with enmty for the other.


TO soften or remove those antiquities, and
promote, between the inhabitants Of the differ
cni sections of our country, community of feel


ing on this momentuous subject, is an object Of
vital Importance, worthy Of the efforts of those
who seek alike the good of all. This cause,
though critical and arctious, is not desperate.
Happily the purbnd philosophy, Which taught
mankind to believe that one part of the com,nu-
nifty could rise only by the depression Of another,
has passed away with the ages that are gone, and
a more enlightened era has dawned. Man is
social being, and finds his own particular advan-
.age in the promotion ofthe general good. Party
strifcs and sectional jcalousies result from crro.
ncous and limited views of private interest; and
ofted from imperfect acquaintance with the mo-
tves by which others arc actnated. The people
of the United States are bound together by one
great federal interest; and however the nhabt-
ants of the north may disapprove and ahhor the
system OF servitude which prevails in tle south,
and however they may compassionate its victims,
there must from their common interests, as well
as common origin, always cXis, in the prejudices
and sympathes Of the former, strong prepon-
QeraHCc IN favour OF lle superior CiaSS


There is probably no subject more deeply in.
teresting to every section of the Union than ne
gro slavery, and none which has stronger claims
ON the clearcst heads and purest hearts among
us. To open way equally safe and salutary,
for the master and the slave to escape from the
evils in which they are involved, and thus to
clear ourselves from the reproach ofhaying disa-
vowed, by our practice, the noble principles on
which we assumed rank among the nations Of
the earth, is the great political problem which
this or some succeeding generation must solve.


Animated by desire to contribute towards
the attainment of this monientous object, and
supported by the encouragement of his friends,
the subscriber has concluded to offer to public
acceptance a monthly periodical journa, with the
title prefixed to this article, designed TO include
an extensive range of enquiries connected with
this subject. To combat the prcjudiccs which
this system has produced, and which have vari-
ed their shades according to the points from
which the condition has been viewed--to trace
the moral influence of slavery on those who
breathe its atmospherc-and to point out the
best means for its peaceful extinction, will be
among the prominent objects of discussion.


The work will comprise the following general
divisions.


1. Sketches of the history, ancient and mod
ern, of Afrca-of the progress of geographical!
discovery therein--of its productions, commerce,
and future prospects; and of the manners, gov

for its aboliton-Is present state; with its effect
on the inhabitants of Africa.


4. The nature and character Of nego slavery
in the Islands and on the continent of America
The internal slave trade within the United States
Laws and usages in relation to slavery, includ-
ing those enacted for its extinction or mellora.
ton.


S. Principles of political economy, i'll relation
to slave abour and consumption compared with
free.


6. Biographical notices Of negroes who have
been distinguished for their virtue or abilities.


z. Plans for improving the condition OF the
slaves in the United States, with an account OF
experiments, on this subject, made by the hold
ers of slaves.


8. View of the situation, character, and future
prospects of the free cooured population OF the
United States.


In the collections which shall be made on
these various topics, the works of the abest wrl-
ters among the ancents and moderns will be
consulted; the narratives of travellers carefully
examined; and such extracts made from the pc
riodical works of the day as shall appear proper
ly calculated to illustrate the subjects embraced
by the plan. Measures are taken to establish an
extensive correspondence with persons OF intel
Grepce and ysraeity. in this country and in Eu,

full articles.headline: SLAVE TRADE.
full articles.article:
The following is a late decree of the King Of
France against the Slave Trade:


"Charles, by the grace of God, King of France
and Navarro, to all who shall see these presents,
greeting.


We have ordained, and do orslain, that the
project of 2 law of the following tenor shall be
presented by our Minister Secretary of State to
the Department Of Marine and the Colonies,
whom We charge to explain its object and to sup
port 1t IN discussion,


Only .4rtscie.--In case Of . cooperation or par
tcipaton, by any means whatever in the traffic
known under the name ofthe negro slave trade,
the propretors, AM supercargocs; the insurers
who ensure it knowingly, the captain or comrnail-
der and other officers ofthe vessel; shall be pun
ishcd with banishnent, and fine equal to the
value OF the ship and cargo.


The finc shall be pronounced conjoin,ly against
the individuals designated in the preceding par
agraph.


The captain and officers shall be further de-
clared incapable Of serving, under any title in
the kiny's navy or The French merchant service.
Other individuals belonging to the crew shall
be punished with imprisonment from months
TO pears. From these are expected, such of
the above mentioned individuals as SHALL within
fifteen days after the vessels arrival, declare to
the commissary of marine, or the magistrates in
the French ports or the French consuls in for
eign ports, the facts which they shall know.


The vessel shall be seized and confiscatsd.


The penalties under the present law are indie
pendent of those which shall be pronounced, in
conformity with the penal code, for other crimes
or offences which may have been committed OH
board the slip.


The law of april Is, 1913, is abrogated


Given in our palace of the Iuileries, Dec. 27
1926; and, of our reign the third.

full articles.headline:
PROPOSALS
For publishing new Periodical Work, to be ell


titled
TIE AFRICAN OBSERVER.

PROPOSALS
full articles.article:
It is our privilege to live in an age Of surpass
ing improvement. The sciences and the arts arc
deeply indebted to the genius and enterprise OF
our contemporaries, and schemes, OF extensive
utility, are now i'll successful operation, Which,
a half century ago, would have been considered
as fit only to supply void in the brain Of maniac,
or to exercise the idle Ingenuity OF a visionary
| protector. by new and etiicacious experiments,
principles in natural science, unknown to our ia
| theirs, have been developed, and new avenues
opened to the enjoyment Of man.


! Oftllose Improvements in physical and politi-
cal science, which have stamped their character
on the last and the passing age, the inhabitants
of the western world claim distinguished share
There ingenuity has displayed its inventions
to the gaze and imitation of the world, and there
the principles OF government have been traced
to their source, and the laws of mmutable us-
tice solemnly proclaimed as the proper basis and
support ofpolitcal institutions.


If we review the periods of our national growth,
and mark our unparalleled progress in the march
of nations, we must subscribe to the sentiment,
that no people have greater cause revercntly to
commemorate the goodness of Beneticent
Creator than the people of these United States.
No where have the choicest blessings of the all
bountifu Parent been spread with amore unspar
ing hand. To no other people, ancient ormodern,
has the cup of felicity been presented with few
er bitter ingredients, or more completely purti-
ed from the lees of political thraldom.


If, Judging the future from the past, We en-
deavour to dclineate our course through ages
yet to come, Il series of pleasing antcipatons
warns the rejecting mind. With afertile soil,
extending through every desirable variety of eli
mate. and capable of affordins all that luxury
! could demand to supply the wants, Or promote
the comfort Of mani with population enlight-
ened and free; with government over which
the laws are supreme, and the people the arbiters
of the law; the way appears open to that nation
al greatness which ambition could not wish to
enhance; and to individual prosperity, in which
discomfort might blush to complain.


Are these the dcusive prospects of a feverish
patriotism, the visions ofpoetry; or are they the
anticipations ofsober reflection Is there no ill
boding omen to dim the light that gttcrs on our
future course1 Alas! one portentous cloud is
impending over some of the farest portions of
our favoured land One dire disease, deeply in
fixed in our national system, has 'sgrown with
our growth. and strengthened with our strength"
The light of freedom, which we so highly prize,
shines on part ofour population only by refiec-
ton, and to them is rather darkness visible" than
light


This appalling subject is forced upon us, how
ever reluctant may feel to investigate its char

full articles.headline: CONDITIONS.
full articles.article:
The work will be published in Philadelphia,
on the first of each month, beginning with the
Fourth month next, each number containing SO
pages printed in double columns.


The price three, dollars per annum, payable
IN aduance


Such of the patrons Of the work as may
choose to withdraw their subscriptions at the ex-
plration OF the year, will be eSpacted to give
notice to the editor or his agent, two months
previously; those who omit forwarding this no
tice will be considered as continuing their sub
scrptions, and their bills presented accordingly.


ENOCH LEWIS.
I'd mo. 22d, 1926.

rope, from whose communications considerable
assistance is anticipated.


The editor being anxious so to conduct his in
vestigatons, that such differ from him in opin-
ion may not be repelled by any appearance of
severity or rudeness, from a'calm and patient at
tention to the facts or arguments adduced, every
thing OF vindicitve character will be carefully
excluded from his columns.


1t may be added that rigid adherence to the
order above exhibited in the arrangement of his
subjects. is not intended, and that several of
those topics will be brought into view in each of
the successive numbers. In the 18th number an
index to the volume will be given.

full articles.article:
so rich harvest as his fancy led him to ex-
pect.


would further remark, that the second.
IS certain nondescript, pettifogging Doc
tor, who is every thing by turns and nothing
long, affecting to be Catholic, and who.
4osan IKE, would destroy the Church. He
has been sowing dscord and dissention a.
mong the members since he came to Will
mington. From whence he came, or who he
is, God only knows. 1t has been said he
formerly resided in Lancaster, but for what
ne left Lancaster, whether by day or night,
for the safety of his carcase. or by the advice
OF tzoefUe honest yeomen, know not.


! am attached to the Catholic church,
which affords me satisfaction; and / feel
pride in promoting the interests of the
Church; and do hope the congregation will
be on their guard against the tricks attempt
ed to be practised OH them by such an un-
principled renegade.


i feel consciousness of the correctness
of the course pursued by me in regard to the
Church, and that it has not only been lust
ana honourable, but that instead of a eaiu.
have sustained a loss, by my attention to
her concerns, which can make appear sa-
tlsfactorly to any unprejudiced mind.


~, WIN. LARKIN.


Wilmington, Feb. 10Th. 1S27.-22-4tp.

full articles.headline: TO TIE PUHrxC.
full articles.article:
very scurrilous publication appeared over
the signatures OF Peter Pierce, Bernard NJ
Gugen, Bernard M'Cann and John Durnin
self styled Trustees Of the Catholic Church,
in Wilmington, in which my character has
been uniustlv assaled, and most wantouly
sandered. ] feel it duty | owe to myself
and my friends, to repel the unauthorized,
base and unfounded charges made by those
calumniators, and expose them to that CON
tempt they merit; by exhibiting to the pub
lie statement OF the facts connected with
the Lottery case alluded to. as briefly as prac-
ticable, with comment, from which they
may be enabled to form their judgments.


1t may be recollected, that on application
of the Trustees of St. Peters Church, at
Wilmington, the Legislature of Delaware,
in 1922, authorized the raising by Lottery,
for the use of the Church, and payment Of
debts, the sum of three thousand dollars, Co.
yer and beyond all expenses); and in that
law named certain Managers to supcrintend
the Lottery; some in Wilmington ard some
in Philadelphia. In conformity with the
provisions of the law, the Managers pro-
ceeded to discharge the trust confided 70
them. After this period the Managers u.
nites,, in opinion, that one Of them should
sign the Tickets, and receive and make pay
ment of prizes. Unfortunately for me, or.
as the self-created Trustees would have it,
for the Church, was selected for that pur-
pose, the residue OF the Managers giving me
their bond of indemnity against any loss in
the performance of that duty.


The Scheme of this Lottery was sold to
Thomas Hope, Broker, by. and with the
consent OF the Managers, for the sum of
three thousand dollars--to be drawn in Six
classes, payable $500 at the drawing OF each
class. Under that arrangement Mr.. Hope
went on, and drew two classes. For those
two classes paid the Church in cash and
Note, and payment of her debts the full a
mount and upwards, say sixteen hundred
and five dollars and fourteen cents. The
Third class of this Lottery. was subsequent
ly under the direction of Patrick Higgins,
and conducted by him, and many OF the tick
cts in that class remained upsold. The prl-
2es in that class was called on tor, and OBJ
lged to pay; by my signing, ! was pledged
TO redeem them. On Hope failing in his en-
ragemeEts the Fourth class was sold to
Messrs Yates and MIntyre. The money
received for the class drawn by them, ac
cording to contract, was applied (and paid)
to the deficiency of the Sd class, conducted
by Patrick Higgins. All OF these facts.
remain ready and willing to make appear in
j
but 7ohich has never been commenced, altho'
so boldly asserted.


As to the denunciation of my services, by
those "Trustees'', it is truly ridiculous.
know of no powers they possess to grant to
me. Ely hozverS are from higher aud
more respectable source. Those men need
employment themselves, and they viii pro-
badly receive it, of that kind in legal wav
not comfortable to them. a part of the JAuaa
Of the Church, would, no doubt, be very con
venient to our "Gentlemen Trustees" but
which it is hoped the good sense OF the con-
gregation will prevent them from handling:
and az very unfortunate indeed would 1t be for
the Church, to confide her concerns in such
hands, goho have not sufficient discretion to
conduct their own affairs. would observe,
that no dissatisfaction would have arose, but
tor two disorganizing members, one OF whom
undertook to perform part i'll the Lottery,
which his incapacty untitled him for, where
by he was abandoued; and he did not reap

The Paris Journal Des Dcbats declares that it
was from Paris that the signal for insurrccton and
civil warm Portugal, was given.


The Bank of Kentucky has been robbed by its
porter ofabout three thousand dollars. 1t is sup
posed that he had false key to the vault.


In Philadelphia last year, 81 vessels were

Ireland.-The Dublin Evening Mail SAYS

which would lead US to lend an car TO the
adventures Of Munchauscn this oc-
casonally producing merry pcals of laugh
ter, throws his host into a good humour,
and being pronounced, in vulgar phrase,
"a clever sort of fellow" his officiousness
is overlooked This his vanity construes in
to admiration.


The Editor says we'll, when he declares
that notice of US is to him like taking a
dose Of physic. This metaphor cannot be
misunderstood. Rcproof like purge, does
not sit we'll upon his stomach nor on his CON
science; and when We are compelled to hold
the mirror of his conduct up before him, that
he may look upon it and blush at his evil do
ings, we do not wonder that he feels the
effects Of a powerful operative. From his
last remarks We have evidence that it also
partakcs of the properties Of an emetic.

"ai.' ialliiiar with all tile prlvacies of our do


hiestlc me- accustomed to hear liberty extolled


as the highest and noblcst of eniovments; and
yet, hndng the bitter draught of hereditary SER


yitnde its own hopeless portion; incapable, from


its degraded condition, ofappreciatng the bless


ings OF the government under which we live, and


having little to dread from any change or convul-


SONS OF the political world-presents to our


view prospect too awful to- be contemplated


with stole Indifference The cloud is thickening


with the progress of time; and prudence adj
monishes, that, if it cannot be dissipated, it
should, # possible, be dsarmcd ofits lightning.
whether slavery is, or is not a political evil,
or whether free or slave population is most
conducive to national prosperity, can scarcely,
IN tins age and in this country, require a serious
discussion.


If slavery has, in all ages, and among all ma
tons, been considered as among the greatest Of
evils, ii liberty is always the highest wish and ul-
tlmatc aim OF the slave, how repusive must that
condition appear to an observant eve, when con-
trasted with the civil and religious freedom, by
which, in the United States, it is every where
surrounded.


But however we may colnmiserate the condi-
tlon OF those who are doomed to hereditary SER
vittlde, the zeal which this feeling excites NAV
sometimes warm without enlightcning The phi
lanthroplc mind. The slave, sunk and degraded
below the proper level ofhumanty, may find in
the letharglc inscnsibiiity resulting FROM his sit
uation, retreat from mental suffering; vet,
though bent to the yoke, he still Possesses the
stamina OF the human chaiacter--thc aspiring
tendency OF his nature, though suppressed and
concealed, is not destroyed-hs dormant pas


sons are not extinct. The TRANQUILITY which


prevails. may be suddenly ,listirbcd-fur the
sumberng volcano retains its fires, and those


who occupy lis smoking verge may themselves
| l,a 4 g =.
| The slave is not the only object that demands
our consideration. The introduction of negro
slavery into the United States was not the work
OF the present generation. The system was en-
tailed upon them by their ancestors: and Justice
| demands the admission, that evils, both moral
and political, are more easily discovered than re-
moved; and that those who arc subjected, by
the circumstances of their birth, to the hard al
Tentative, either to new model the habits which
! have grown with their years, or to maintain
system which their sober judgments cannot an
prove, are objects of sympathy with the truly
christian mind.


The .iealouses and antpatlles which the dis
| tlnction between slave-holding and non slave
| holding states has cngendered and fed, may be
safely cassed among the disastrous concomitants
OF the system; especially as they oppose stub
born obstacle to any general effort for the reno
val OF the other acknowledged evils of slavery.
Unhapply for the cause of humanity, the advo-
! cate Of the slave has been too often identified
with the antag mist Of his owner The interests
OF these opposite classes have been considered
as incompatible, and friendship for tile one AS
synonymous with enmty for the other.


TO soften or remove those antiquities, and
promote, between the inhabitants Of the differ
cni sections of our country, community of feel


ing on this momentuous subject, is an object Of
vital Importance, worthy Of the efforts of those
who seek alike the good of all. This cause,
though critical and arctious, is not desperate.
Happily the purbnd philosophy, Which taught
mankind to believe that one part of the com,nu-
nifty could rise only by the depression Of another,
has passed away with the ages that are gone, and
a more enlightened era has dawned. Man is
social being, and finds his own particular advan-
.age in the promotion ofthe general good. Party
strifcs and sectional jcalousies result from crro.
ncous and limited views of private interest; and
ofted from imperfect acquaintance with the mo-
tves by which others arc actnated. The people
of the United States are bound together by one
great federal interest; and however the nhabt-
ants of the north may disapprove and ahhor the
system OF servitude which prevails in tle south,
and however they may compassionate its victims,
there must from their common interests, as well
as common origin, always cXis, in the prejudices
and sympathes Of the former, strong prepon-
QeraHCc IN favour OF lle superior CiaSS


There is probably no subject more deeply in.
teresting to every section of the Union than ne
gro slavery, and none which has stronger claims
ON the clearcst heads and purest hearts among
us. To open way equally safe and salutary,
for the master and the slave to escape from the
evils in which they are involved, and thus to
clear ourselves from the reproach ofhaying disa-
vowed, by our practice, the noble principles on
which we assumed rank among the nations Of
the earth, is the great political problem which
this or some succeeding generation must solve.


Animated by desire to contribute towards
the attainment of this monientous object, and
supported by the encouragement of his friends,
the subscriber has concluded to offer to public
acceptance a monthly periodical journa, with the
title prefixed to this article, designed TO include
an extensive range of enquiries connected with
this subject. To combat the prcjudiccs which
this system has produced, and which have vari-
ed their shades according to the points from
which the condition has been viewed--to trace
the moral influence of slavery on those who
breathe its atmospherc-and to point out the
best means for its peaceful extinction, will be
among the prominent objects of discussion.


The work will comprise the following general
divisions.


1. Sketches of the history, ancient and mod
ern, of Afrca-of the progress of geographical!
discovery therein--of its productions, commerce,
and future prospects; and of the manners, gov
4 ~.

II Aswe expected, the Editor Of the Gazette
n has "come out'' in his usual style, in reilly
N IA our remark Of last week. AS usual. when
Y he meets an opponent, honourable weapons
81 and ,he garb Of deccncy are laid aside, and
the "creature" presents itself as nature
made it. There is no better way to as
n certain the real character and composition
q Of the Editor than to touch him in vulner
4 HE mart, The arrow Of truth at once shows
an analyzing propcrty--the mass becomes
distracted, decomposes, and begins to sep
X arate--the airy and offensive parts float to
surface, and vapor of in disgusting ctfluvia,
d to the annoyance of all whose olfactores
n come in contact with it; whilst the nooionS
" sink to the bottom and discover the close
y adherng properties Of malice, envy, and ha-
III tired. with some small but brilliant particles
II Of hypocrisy.


n We will say but little of has practices in the


intercourse Of private life. He has been,


since he was first elected into this state OF


transiorF being most part Of his life, mo
Mic character. We knew him when a boy
Elwhen he trunneled the hoop, raised the airy
H kite, and participated with his little play
ssmates in the editying amusement of "hidc
Hand 20 seek. When he was exalted to the
station of oflacquey to a storekeeper, and af-
4 tcrwards aped his masters part. We knew
Z him when he was appointed to the dignifed
station of Cctloral Of a company of mlitia,--
swhen he figured as auctoneer and Knocked


3oh books at a penny pece--when he shone
Tout as professor of music, (amateur q la
fmode) and taught the fascinating science Of
fla, sol, la and with what zeal he would walk
ia mile or so, to be made a butt of by a score
LOT country urchins; when upon certain oc


casion, in one of his nocturnal excur-


sons, his delectable person came in contact
with the clements of horse -fiond; and last


ly, when the establishment of the Delaware
y Gazette was purchased and he put into it as


the nominal editor. This is a short sketch


Of the ..creature's" pedigree, and we would


if we had time, and more inclination, embel-
lish it with a few amusing incidents. This,


however, may be done at some future time,


when we Will paint him, if not with fair col


ours, in bold ones, as with tar trash.
4 We are by no means surprised when Mr..
Z Harker says several members of the Legis-

per as the Wilmingtonian printed in this

t3or how could they have overlooked al
IN name which has so often graced the columns
81 OF that paper, as its rival in public favor.
II That such ignorance should be ekcd by a |
h legislator is by no means surprising: such,
II We presume to be his friends--precious lu-
# mlnaries
The Editor hreanmes that we will not
contradict falsehood which he again advan-
Ses. Were we to occupy ourselves in con-
Il 1ladicting his falschoods, we should not have


uine for any thing else--and as he is known
H sohave but little veneration for the truth,
@ewill allow him all the latitude he requires.
4 Therefore,
--do what we may,
n ihe will bark-the will ever Bray"
mans standing in private life is usually
marked by his general department. We
10 not know that Mr.. Harker has ever had,


among all his visionary pretensions, any


lain to gentility. We never knew him to


'e admitted into genteel company upon the


S'ale OF equality. He has been admitted


~ nave servants and waiting men. When

We apologize to our readers for the no
tice wc have descended TO take to-day of
the Editor of the Delaware Gazette. We
promise that in future, unless called upon by
an imperious sense Of dufy, we shall let the
"crcature" alone. We would not at this
time have spoken, had it not been to expose
falsehood. retute caumny, and throw igno-

all extensive range of enquiries connected with
this subject. To combat the prejudccs which
this system has produced, and which have vari-
ed their shades according to the points from
which the condition has been vlewed--to trace
the moral influence of slavery on those who
breathe its atmospherc-and to point out the
best means for its peaceful extinction, will be
among the prominent objects of discussion.
The work will comprise the following general
divisions.


1. Sketches Of the history, ancient and mod
crl, of Afrca-of the progress of geographica!
discovery therein--ofi its productions, commerce,
and future prospects,; and of the manners, gov
ernment, and arts of the negro race.


g. The history, character, and incidents of
slavery among the ancicnts, with its decline and
extinction among the moderns.


8. The African slave trade. Its history char
acter, and extent-Efforts that have been used
for its aboliton-Is present state; with its effect
on the inhabitants of Africa.


4. The nature and character Of nego slavery
in the Islands and on the continent of America
The internal slave trade within the United States
Laws and usages in relation to slavery, includ-
ing those enacted for its extinction or mellora.
ton.


S. Principles of political economy, i'll relation
to slave abour and consumption compared with
free.


6. Biographical notices Of negroes who have
been distinguished for their virtue or abilities.


z. Plans for improving the condition OF the
slaves in the United States, with an account OF
experiments, on this subject, made by the hold
ers of slaves.


8. View of the situation, character, and future
prospects of the free cooured population OF the
United States.


In the collections which shall be made on
these various topics, the works of the abest wrl-
ters among the ancents and moderns will be
consulted; the narratives of travellers carefully
examined; and such extracts made from the pc
riodical works of the day as shall appear proper
ly calculated to illustrate the subjects embraced
by the plan. Measures are taken to establish an
extensive correspondence with persons OF intel
